misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Overgeneralizing from math class about “nice” numeric output
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they compute a cost using doubles and print it, Java will automatically display it as a normal money amount (e.g., exactly 2 decimal places) rather than a long decimal expansion.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `double` is a binary floating‑point type, so many decimal values cannot be represented exactly. When you concatenate a `double` with a `String`, Java converts the `double` to text with a default conversion (not “money formatting”), which may show many digits. To display currency, you must explicitly format (e.g., `printf("%.2f")` or `NumberFormat`).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Output looks "messy" (too many decimal places) or slightly different from expected currency formatting; not a compile/runtime error.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that closing a Scanner is a standard cleanup procedure that only affects the Scanner object itself, without consequences for other parts of the program.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, closing a Scanner that is wrapped around System.in also closes the underlying standard input stream. This is a global side effect: once System.in is closed, it cannot be reopened, preventing any other part of the program from reading console input later. While not fatal in this single-method script, it demonstrates a flawed understanding of resource lifecycles and stream management.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the double data type is the appropriate way to represent and calculate monetary values because it supports decimal numbers.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student is unaware that 'double' uses binary floating-point representation (IEEE 754), which cannot exactly represent many base-10 decimal fractions (like $0.10). This leads to cumulative rounding errors. In professional Java development, money should be represented using BigDecimal or an integer type like long to store values in cents, ensuring base-10 precision.
